significance: Jerusalem, Israel Solomon's Temple, also known as the First Temple (Hebrew: ×‘ÖµÖ¼×™×ªÖ¾×”Ö·×Ö´Ö¼×§Ö°×“Ö¸Ö¼×©× ×”Ö¸×¨Ö´××©××•Ö¹×Ÿ, Beit HaMikdash HaRishon), was the first holy temple of the ancient Israelites, built in Jerusalem during the reign of King Solomon around 957 BCE. It served as the primary center of Israelite worship and housed the Ark of the Covenant in its innermost sanctuary, the Holy of Holies. The Second Temple, rebuilt after the Babylonian exile and later expanded by Herod, became the setting for significant events in early Christianity, including Peter's healing at the Beautiful Gate and his sermon in Solomon's Porch (Acts 3).

secondTemple.description: The Second Temple (516 BCE - 70 CE) replaced Solomon's Temple and was later magnificently expanded by Herod the Great. This was the Temple in which Jesus and the apostles ministered.
secondTemple.herodianExpansion: King Herod's expansion doubled the Temple Mount's size and added numerous porticoes, including Solomon's Porch (Stoa of Solomon) on the eastern side.

significantAreas.beautifulGate: The gate between the Court of the Gentiles and the Court of Women, where Peter healed the lame man (Acts 3:2)
significantAreas.solomonsPorch: A covered colonnade on the east side of the Temple Mount where Peter preached after the healing (Acts 3:11) and where early believers gathered (Acts 5:12)
significantAreas.courtOfGentiles: Outer court accessible to all peoples - Jesus cleansed this area of money changers
significantAreas.courtOfWomen: Inner court accessible to Jewish women and men
significantAreas.holyOfHolies: Innermost sanctuary, entered only by the high priest on Yom Kippur

apostolicMinistry.description: The Temple continued as a center of worship and teaching for early Jewish Christians

petrineEvents.description: Peter and John healed a man lame from birth at the ninth hour of prayer, declaring 'Silver and gold have I none; but such as I have give I thee: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk.'
After the healing, crowds gathered in Solomon's Porch where Peter preached about Jesus as the fulfillment of the prophets, quoting Moses and connecting Jesus to the Abrahamic blessing
The priests and Sadducees arrested Peter and John for teaching about resurrection in Jesus, but about 5,000 men believed
The early church continued meeting in Solomon's Porch, performing signs and wonders among the people
The apostles were imprisoned but an angel released them, commanding them to 'Go, stand and speak in the temple to the people all the words of this life'

apostolicMinistry.continuedObservance: Early Jewish Christians continued Temple worship (Acts 2:46, 3:1), seeing Christianity as the fulfillment rather than abolition of Judaism
